body.p: A byte by itself is quite small, so we have terms such as kilobyte, megabyte, and gigabyte to measure larger collections of bytes. These terms are used to measure, for example, the size of a JPEG file or the capacity of a thumb drive.
One kilobyte (kB) is about 1000 bytes (see below for why the word "about" is necessary here). So for example 5,000 bytes is about 5 kB.

One page of ordinary alphabetic text takes about 2 kB to store (about 1 byte per letter, as in the previous section). A typical short email also takes up just 1 or 2 kB. Text is very compact, requiring few bytes compared to images and sound and video.

One megabyte (MB) is about 1 million bytes (or equivalently, about 1000 KB). A rule of thumb for MP3 audio is that 1 minute of audio requires about 1 MB. A high-quality digital image is, on average, 2 to 5 MB. Audio and image and video data typically are stored in compressed form.

One gigabyte (GB) is about 1 billion bytes, or 1000 MB. Gigabyte was once a rarely used term, but as technology advanced, increasing the speed and storage capacities of computers, it has become a commonly used unit. In 2017, a computer might have 8 or 16 GB of RAM and 256 or 512 GB of persistent storage. A BluRay video disk can store about 50 GB.
One terabyte (TB) is about 1 trillion bytes, or 1000 GB. In 2017, 10 TB is about the largest consumer hard drive available.
It's useful to be able to solve simple word problems about kilobytes, megabytes, and gigabytes. Mostly this involves using the number 1000 to translate between units. Here is one example problem:
Problem: Alice has 100 small images, each of which is 500 kB. How much total space do they take up in megabytes (MB)?
Solution: There are 100 images, and each image is 500 kB. So the total size is 100 Ã— 500 kB = 50,000 kB. 1000 kB is 1 MB, so 50,000 kB is 50 MB. The answer is 50 MB.

The text above says that 1 kB is about 1000 bytes. Why is the word about needed? For units such as kilobytes and megabytes, there are two systems. The 1000 system uses a factor of 1000 between kilobytes, megabytes, and so on, as is common with the SI metric system. Our word problems will use this simple 1000 system. There is also a 1024 system that uses a factor of 1024 between units. This is because computers are based on the binary system and memory is measured in powers of 2. In the 1024 system, 1 KB is equal to 210 or 1024 bytes. Deep within the computer, grouping things by factors of 1024 is convenient, which is why the 1024 system exists.

In an attempt to fix the confusion between the 1000 and 1024 systems, the terms kibibyte, mebibyte, gibibyte, and tebibyte have been introduced to specifically mean the 1024-based units (see Kibibyte on Wikipedia). These terms do not seem to have caught on very strongly yet.
